displayed_text: Family Member: - and weak, is there someone I can call? Doctor: Yeah me. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: You would page me and if it’s not me it’s the doctor covering me um and if it’s you can’t get anybody, you call uh if it’s severe you call the ambulance, you call nine one one. Family Member: Nine one one yeah right, right, right. Okay. Doctor: Yeah um hmm. Family Member: And we will have a number to call? Doctor: Oh yeah, yep. And I do want to mention as you’re talking about this, he’s also an Iron Man candidate. Healthcare Professional: Okay. Doctor: So in our quest to always get you the most number of trials Mr. W____ that you’re eligible for, (HCP laughs) Family Member: Um, hum. Doctor: - so that I know and everyone else knows how you’re doing, how you’re feeling –

Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Because that also would be a possibility, i.e., come off the trial, do some chemotherapy with the K___ oncologist, and then on the back end, when the chemotherapy is over, come back and do a different clinical trial at that point. Patient: Um hum. Okay. Okay. Okay. And, again, that’s one of the reasons why I wanted to come here, uh, uh, from the um perspective of the options. And, uh, and I, I, maybe I shouldn’t say this because your recorder is here, but I do like, not only the professionalism here, but, I, I like the sense of, uh, caring that the personnel here, uh, express. That’s from everybody within the building when you, when you come in. But the other thing is, when I come here to get lab work done, uh, I only get stuck one time. You know? I don’t like to be a big pincushion and you’ve gotten stuck four or five times, and the person still hasn’t hit the vein. Can I try your other arm? And I’m thinking like, come on, now. This, this reminds me of the time when I was in the Marine Corp. The corpsman do the stuff on purpose. You know? Doctor: Okay. Patient: So it is what it is. But I said that to say the quality of care and the compassion I can see here at J___ H___. I’m not saying it’s not there at K___. There’s some good doctors there, good personnel, that have been very helpful to me. Uh, but, uh, I see it all through the building here when I come here. That’s one thing. I could see it. Doctor: So are we all on the same page now? Patient: Yes. Doctor: It sounds like we’re going to keep you on the study for now. In order to do so, we have to stop the medication to allow this anemia to recover. Hopefully, it will. Uh, so as of today, uh, no more Patient: Okay. Doctor: Until you come back and see us on September the fifth. Uh, L___ will be in touch with you after she comes back. Family Member: She’ll be here tomorrow. Doctor: She actually had to leave unexpectedly because her house had some flooding which she had to take care of, which is why she’s not here.

Patient: I haven’t had chemo there. Doctor: But I’m talking scans. Patient: Scans. Yeah I’ve had scans at Hospital B and also Hospital C at O____ and also the Hospital A, so in M____. So you know it doesn’t make any difference really to me, yeah. Doctor: Great, I just want to make sure that they can be compared so that we can get a sense of what’s changed- Patient: Yeah. Doctor: because if everything’s stable even though your PSA is going up, we might wait longer. If the pictures show more cancer and your PSA is higher Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: you know and then that’s the information that says okay, what do we do next? Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: You know say I don’t like any of those trials that (names person) Family Member: Mm, hmm. Patient: Yeah, well I’m in favor of the trials. Family Member: There are a lot more side effects with the trials.

Patient: Ah. Doctor: That’s a bad thing. Patient: Oh. Okay. Doctor: That says, um, (laughs) Patient: I see. Doctor: Uh. So you almost have to do something that’s not chemotherapy. Sorry. Something that’s not hormone therapy. Patient: Okay. Is that the – Doctor: Xtandi. Patient: Xtandi. Okay. That was a shot once a month or? Doctor: That was the pills you were taking. Patient: Oh, I did take them. Yeah. Okay. Doctor: So that would say if we did that just as a course of action and the likelihood it’s gonna help you is pretty low. Patient: Oh.

Patient: Uh (relation) Doctor: So it’s not direct. It would be well I’m super tired or my stomach doesn’t feel good then I eat and drink less. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And then you’re dehydrated and your - and organ like kidney or liver takes a hit. Patient: Okay. Family Member: Gotcha. Doctor: That’s the problem. Patient: I’m not eating less. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: I do feel that I’m eating better… Um… Family Member: Mhmm. Doctor: Yeah because you got a week off.

Patient: What kind of pills? Doctor: So these are FDA-approved pills called Xtandi, which is the trade name. Uh, they’re four pills once a day, and their primary goal of how they work is it’s, it’s like a big hormone pill again. So it’s to help your shot work better. It also is approved by the FDA because it helps you live longer. No cures. Same as we were before but we need to get a handle on all these things in the lung. In the same way, you’re also a candidate for chemo to tell you the truth. Uh, so chemo’s in the mix as well, but the majority of folks I think, and I’m not saying you do, but my patients tend to prefer pills before going on to chemotherapy, and I think way back when we initially again reconnected you were not in so much favor of chemo, uh, as he’s already shaking his head, but I want to bring that up again because at some point we may need to go to chemo. So I want to put that out there still. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, but we do have a set of pills. Now, the good news is every time there’s an approved medication, you know, we’re at K______, so we do a lot of clinical studies. So one of our studies is to use that same medication and see if we add a second pill to half the group whether you’d respond better. So I like that study because it’s all pills and no one gets a placebo when you’re thinking about the Xtandi pills. Everyone is on the regular pill that is approved. The question of the placebo versus the other drug is extra. Okay? So I’m not sure if that makes sense or if you’ve got questions with that, but we’re going to try hard to have you be, you know, considered for that study. Uh, I want you to still recover well from your, your hospitalization, but, uh, but that’s in the works for us to consider. The other part is either way, however we move forward, there’s another study, which is a registry study, called, Iron Man. Uh, not that you become iron man- Patient: Hum. Doctor: but that all your experiences as to what’s happened to you get captured. And that means you write out and answer questionnaires. I write out and answer questionnaires. Uh, and then about once a year we take some blood to see what’s happening uh in terms of new research. Uh, and that participation’s pretty cool because a lot of other men around the world are, are participating. And so we get answers from guys from Australia, Ireland, uh, you know, England uh, gosh, Canada, France, so all of that. So everyone’s experience will be captured. And they’re all like you, in the same boat. So we hope you consider that as well. Uh, but I think what we might do is workup to make sure that you’re eligible for all that stuff. I want to introduce you to M___, who’s our research nurse, uh, who just wants to say hi, and then I think we’ll have you come back in a couple weeks when you feel like you’re a little bit stronger. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: How, how long have you been home now? Patient: Two days or- Family Member: Three days. Doctor: From S___’s. Yes. So I, I need you to be two weeks, walking around, not back in the hospital, fully recovered- Patient: Um hum.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay. Questions. Patient: Well, the first question is of course- Doctor: Yep. Patient: -is side effects. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: I haven't gotten, gotten down to that. Doctor: Oh, are you reading the consent? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Yeah, so you know what I mean. Doctor: Mmm. Didn’t they give you a bigger version before you go blind looking at your phone, because it's like 30 pages of that stuff- Patient: Yeah, yeah.

Patient: Okay. I am getting a shot today? Doctor: Um hum. Patient: And I do have it here? Doctor: I think so. Was there a question on that? Patient: I don’t know. Doctor: Okay. Patient: I wasn’t aware of- Doctor: Like. No. I think it’s okay. I think K___ has everything. So we’re good. Okay. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Alright. I just want to double check. You scared the heck out of me last time. So I’m just gonna I don’t know keep an eye on you just a little bit closer - Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: -until I’m confident that I can let you go for three months. Family Member: Right. (Laughter)

Patient: Okay. Doctor: He tells me every time you see him once a month because he draws blood work and everything so then I know you pop up in my systems like oh, you’re in the systems. So, if there’s issues though like things that aren’t going right and you feel whatever, you tell him but then you could always come back to see me anytime. Patient: Okay. Doctor: I’m just gonna put, I’m trying to think, am I giving you the shot or is that your neurologist? Who’s giving you the Lupron? Patient: You are. Doctor: So, you’d have to come back anyways. Did you get a shot today or are you coming? Patient: No, we got one last uh two weeks. Doctor: So, we’ll figure out when your next one is and you’ll come back for that for sure Patient: Okay. Doctor: and then just know you can call anytime and come back in between. Patient: Okay. Alright. Doctor: And then the chemo we’ll just push back but just know it’s around.

Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: If patients are a Gleason score of eight or more, high risk of progression. Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: If it’s a Gleason score of seven I would consider that and intermediate risk and a Gleason score of seven Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: Two ways of having a Gleason score of seven. Three plus four is seven or equals seven. Those two um numbers are different depending Gleason if Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: So if the majority of your Gleason pattern is higher than tree, and the small minority is higher than four, since you have more of the four and less then the three to more Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: If you are a lot more than then they’re gonna Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: So you have an intermediate risk, but potentially . Okay?

Family Member: Oh, okay. Doctor: So that’s their new thing. They don’t need the catheter sometimes. Family Member: Oh, good, good. Doctor: You know? If you’re seventy-five, the veins aren’t so hot for it to hold for three hours, two, three hours, but I think with you it might be just fine. Family Member: Would you-? Okay. Doctor: So I think that’s one step where we could possibly save. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Yes. And then, of course, you know, we do do this, and I really want you to consider, you know, donating the extra bloods as we go throughout the year because I get to follow you for this whole time anyways. Family Member: Oh, okay. Doctor: So it’s not like you have to come back, and he’s, it’s just when you come back, when we stick you, we can get up to like ten extra tubes of blood because it’s that much we have to check. Family Member: Oh. Doctor: Your immune system is really complicated.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.3 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::3 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.neutral: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::neutral

You completely trust doctors' decisions.agree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::agree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.neutral: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::neutral

All in all, you trust doctors completely.agree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::agree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.neutral: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::neutral

People of my ethnic group are treated th.neutral: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::neutral

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.neutral: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::neutral

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.College graduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::College graduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.Yes, Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::Yes, Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.White: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::White

displayed_text: Patient: So do we schedule the appointment today? Doctor: For coming downtown? Yeah somebody will call you once we have everything. Patient: And so we’re not scheduling it today. Doctor: Do you want to come later on this week? Tell me what day works well and how long you need to think about the consent and everything? Patient: Just coming to the midtown? Family Member: To do the tests honey. Doctor: Yeah to do the testing and to do the… Family Member: Is this the long day. Is the first day the long day? Doctor: Oh no, no that’s not treatment day. It’s just pre – all of the screening and testing will happen that day. Family Member: So what would that – that’s an echo and what else? Doctor: Yeah I think the echo and the specialized blood work that we have to send out. Family Member: So there’s just echo and blood work.

Patient: Yeah well I had the flu and it was pneumonia the same time about three years ago. Doctor: Umm. I don’t know if that’s what it is, but guess what. I’m gonna send you to this good doctor. Dr. S____. He’s right in this clinic also and he’s gonna check you out. He’s probably gonna um make some recommendations about what to do for us to figure this out. But I think that’s important too. Now the good part is you’re already getting the shots. Patient: Um hmmm. Doctor: And you know your PSA was coming down just from doing that. That part’s great but I don’t want to miss all the little details. I want to be right on top of this. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? Any questions? Patient: I feel great. Doctor: I was going to say, you look great. I know this is you know waah why can’t we just get this done. But I don’t want to miss anything for you. Patient: Ahhh no I feel great. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: I have no problems… Doctor: That’s awesome.

Family Member: Is there even someone up that way even? I mean, I don't know. Doctor: I think so. Family Member: I think Dr. F_____. Doctor: They kind of go out like, yeah, there's somebody that's out there like once a week or once a month, they rotate. Family Member: So they come out and do infusions? Doctor: No, I think the infusion people are there all the time. I think the doctors come out every so often. Family Member: Ohh. Okay. Doctor: Don’t quote me. Patient: So I only have to come down once every three weeks? Yeah. Family Member: So what's the difference between the trial infusion timetable and the infusion of just getting the infusions. Doctor: None. It's still once every three weeks. Family Member: Yeah, there's no difference? Doctor: There's no difference. So it's just if you get on the study arm and you get the pill chemo version, then you might have a slightly different schedule. And I should know all that except I rely heavily on my research nurse to make sure that's right. Because they change the schedule sometimes so often, and I'm just gonna so ask S____ to help me.

Family Member: I thought I would mention it ‘cuz I think for her – Doctor: I don’t know enough about that. I’d have to read up about that, but I don’t think it relates. Family Member: For her, it was a really easy fix. Doctor: That’s not a gene on this panel that they did for you. Family Member: Oh, okay. Doctor: They do more common cancer genes. Family Member: Oh, I see. Doctor: I think that’s a little more unusual gene. So. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: So, whether that’s what it is -- Family Member: It affected pregnancy. So, that’s why it was in our family, but also Doctor: Did they test her children or anything or? Family Member: Uh, no she doesn’t have children.
